He shares recipes he's been cooking, restaurants he's been eating at, and more. It gets better: If you sign up for our newsletter, you'll get this letter before everyone else.When you’ve got a mother-in-law who’s allergic to shellfish, an 11-year-old who won’t look at the stuff, a wife who is obsessed with linguine vongole, and a father in law who asks why you didn’t buy more clams, that’s when you make two pastas for dinner.To be clear, I’m not suggesting anyone else actually do this. But it was an interesting exercise, at least, in shared stove-top negotiations and marital relations.Simone’s parents were visiting for the weekend, along with Cousin Tony (who was firmly on Team Vongole), and Simone announced she was making her favorite pasta for dinner. She alerted me that I was on the hook for something that both Marlon and her mom would like.Without missing a beat, I settled on Molly Baz’s pasta al limone, a luscious, super simple recipe, fit for grandmas and grandsons alike.On a tight four-burner stove, we filled up a big stock pot with liberally salted water. Into that would go enough dried pasta for both dishes—a little over a pound for five people.Want this letter before it hits the website? Sign up for our newsletter!Who can say no to this pasta al limone?
Photo by Chelsie Craig, Food Styling by Kate BuckensMeanwhile, in a cast-iron paella pan, Simone set to work on the clams, filling it with a few glugs of olive oil, and some smashed garlic. Eventually, in went two dozen little necks, a generous splash of rosé and, because it’s August, a big handful of sun gold tomatoes.Elbow to elbow, I started on the limone sauce in an oval Dutch oven. Heavy cream, butter, lemon zest. Simmer.Just as the spaghetti chitarra was approaching al dente, we added a cup of starchy pasta water to each cooking vessel to help emulsify the sauces. We then tonged the pasta straight into pots and I showered the creamy limone with a handful of finely grated parm.Despite my initial skepticism, we got both pastas to the table simultaneously, all hot and saucy and glossy. I won’t say which was better (no point in starting an argument with my wife now, given we emerged from our cook-off unscathed). I’ll just say that maybe making two pastas for dinner isn’t such a crazy idea, after all.Get the recipes:BA's Best Linguine and ClamsClams vary in brininess and the amount of liquid they’ll release during cooking, so you’ll need to adjust the salt and add pasta water accordingly. To prevent the sauce from getting too salty, we recommend a measured amount of salt for the pasta water. If possible, look for an artisanal dried pasta for this recipe—the rougher surface texture will catch the slippery sauce better.View Recipe Pasta al LimoneThis creamy lemon pasta recipe is luscious and amply cheesy, but still bright and fresh.
